title: The Easiest Ways to Prevent Your Cat from Chewing on Wires

steps.title: Use wire covers and sheaths.
steps.content: Use wire covers and sheaths. Wire covers and sheaths obscure your cords and chargers with tubing, which prevents your cat from having easy access. All you have to do is wrap the cover around the cord to provide easy, cat-proof coverage. If you have a pretty massive cord setup, a cord reel might help with this.

steps.title: Cover the wires in foil.
steps.content: Cover the wires in foil. Pet owners have found that cats aren’t huge fans of aluminum foil, and may steer clear of surfaces where foil is present. [1] X Research source Use this hack to your own advantage by wrapping some of your cat’s favorite cords with sections of foil.

steps.title: Apply double-sided tape to the wires.
steps.content: Apply double-sided tape to the wires. Cats aren’t known to love the feeling of sticky tape, and may avoid surfaces that are covered in it. Wrapping up an entire length of cord in double-sided tape may help prevent your cat from sinking their teeth into it again. Duct tape can also be an effective way to cover up your cords. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Spritz the cords with a bitter apple spray or other deterrent.
steps.content: Spritz the cords with a bitter apple spray or other deterrent. Bitter apple sprays coat a given surface in an unpleasant (but totally safe!) flavor that cats hate. Give your wires a good spray-down to help your kitty get the message. [3] X Research source You can also use a product like Chewsafe Cord Cover , a safe but foul-tasting clear cover for your cables. Dish soap is another possible option—just make sure to add more periodically. Steer clear of using substances like garlic to coat your wires, which is poisonous to cats. [4] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source

steps.title: Set carpet grippers near the wires.
steps.content: Set carpet grippers near the wires. Some pet owners have noticed that their cats aren’t huge fans of the bumpy texture that carpet grippers have. With this in mind, they may stay away from spots where you lay them down (like near cords and chargers).

steps.title: Remove unnecessary electronics from your space.
steps.content: Remove unnecessary electronics from your space. Take a look at all the cords, chargers, and their respective electronics in your living space. Do you use all of these devices regularly, or can some of them (and their wires) be put away? Clearing away some cords will definitely stop your cat from chewing them. For instance, you might retire your old VHS player, or a lamp that you barely use.

steps.title: Block off the wires so your cat can’t get to them.
steps.content: Block off the wires so your cat can’t get to them. See if there are any clever ways you can totally hide your cords so your cat doesn’t have easy access. For example, you might plug your TV into an outlet behind the dresser it’s perched on, rather than using an extension cord. [5] X Research source Cord cover kits can be an effective way to hide and block away cords from your cats.

steps.title: Tape all dangling cords down so that they don't dangle.
steps.content: Tape all dangling cords down so that they don't dangle. It's the dangling that often attracts the cat; once taped firmly to a table leg or wall, the cord blends in and ceases to provide the same attraction. You can also purchase Velcro attachments or special cord clips to keep cords attached flatly to another item.

steps.title: Switch off and unplug electronics when they aren’t in use.
steps.content: Switch off and unplug electronics when they aren’t in use. While this technically won’t stop your cats from chewing your wires, it will protect them in the event that they continue to chomp on your precious cables. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Invest in GFCI outlets and surge protectors for your wires.
steps.content: Invest in GFCI outlets and surge protectors for your wires. GFCI outlets and surge protectors help identify and shut down electrical surges before any person (or animal) can be hurt by them. Surge protectors are easy to set up, while GFCI outlets take a little more time and electrical know-how to wire and install . [7] X Research source Always call an electrician or handy-person if you aren’t comfortable installing or otherwise modifying your home’s outlets.

steps.title: Give your cats safe and enriching toys.
steps.content: Give your cats safe and enriching toys. If your cat is totally enriched and entertained by their environment, they might not feel the need to gnaw on any nearby cords. Some great options to consider include: [8] X Research source Laser pointers Puzzle feeders Wand toys Brown paper bags (with the handles taken off) or cardboard boxes

steps.title: Create an enriching environment for your cat.
steps.content: Create an enriching environment for your cat. Make sure that your cat has the ability and space to jump onto a high, vertical surface, like a cat tree or cat condo . Having accessible windowsills with visible birdbaths can also be incredibly stimulating for your cat. [9] X Research source Tip: Make sure your cat has plenty of comfy places where they can relax, too, like a roomy bedroom closet or a spot under your bed.

steps.title: Play with and spend lots of time with your cat.
steps.content: Play with and spend lots of time with your cat . Giving your cat lots of love, attention, and entertainment is a great way to keep them out of trouble (or, at least, out of your cords). [10] X Research source Schedule around two 15- or 20-minute play periods with your cat each day to make sure they’re getting enough stimulation. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Personal enjoyment
steps.content: Personal enjoyment Some cats just like the way chewing feels to them, and might especially enjoy the texture of a cord or charger. [12] X Research source Tip: Make sure your cat has plenty of engaging toys and enriching activities that they can use and enjoy, so they can be entertained beyond an electrical cord.

steps.title: Curiosity
steps.content: Curiosity Cats are naturally curious creatures with built-in hunting instincts. To some cats, the shape and position of a cord may pique their curiosity and help stimulate these instincts.

steps.title: Boredom
steps.content: Boredom Some cats are looking for mental enrichment and use chewing as a means of passing the time. If you suspect that your kitty is bored, make sure you’re dedicating plenty of time to play with them each day. [13] X Research source Tip: Try to make time for around two 15-20 minute play times with your cat each day to keep them engaged. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Pleasant texture
steps.content: Pleasant texture Many cord covers are made with a slightly pliable substance. Some cats might like the “give” this substance offers to their teeth, which may encourage them to chew cables more frequently.

steps.title: Pica
steps.content: Pica Pica is a behavioral issue that revolves around chewing on/eating items that aren’t meant to be eaten. [15] X Research source A cat with pica might be more inclined to chew on non-edible items, like cords and chargers.

steps.title: Anxiety and stress
steps.content: Anxiety and stress When cats feel stressed, their anxiety can manifest in pretty destructive ways—like chewing electrical cords, for example. Compulsive orders can be an addition to this type of behavior, a stressed cat may also hide away more than they typically do, drink and eat their meals less than they normally would (or eat more than usual, alternatively), meow more than usual, and/or groom themselves too much. [16] X Research source Certain cat breeds are a little more inclined to feel anxious and experience separation anxiety, like the Siamese cat. [17] X Research source A compulsive disorder may also contribute to chewing behaviors. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Dental issues
steps.content: Dental issues If your cat chews on cords frequently, it could mean that there’s an issue with their teeth or dental health overall. Visit your vet so they can take a closer look at your kitty and see if a dental-related issue could be causing the unwanted behavior. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Choking
steps.content: Choking As a cat chews and gnaws on an electrical cord, they might end up nibbling off small pieces of the wire covering, which can pose a choking hazard. If your cat appears to be choking, you can actually give them a feline version of the Heimlich Maneuver by holding them with their back to your chest (so they’re dangling). Then, place your hand over their abdomen and push/propel your hand up 5 times to help dislodge the obstruction. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Burns
steps.content: Burns Thermal burns (caused by electricity) are very real issues that can stem from a cat chewing on a live wire. If your kitty was recently burned, you might notice an injury near their mouth that looks gray, light yellow, tan. [21] X Research source The burn will form wherever the cat was exposed to live electricity; in this case, that would likely be around the mouth.

steps.title: Electrocution
steps.content: Electrocution Chewing on a plugged-in cord can cause a cat to be exposed to a live electrical current, which can lead to serious side effects like seizures, muscle spasms, tummy pain, a pulmonary edema (a condition where liquid collects in the lungs), vomiting, cardiac arrest, and more. [22] X Research source

steps.title: A mix of deterrents and extra stimulation can keep cats from chewing cords.
steps.content: A mix of deterrents and extra stimulation can keep cats from chewing cords. Deterrents like cord covers, bitter sprays, and foil can be effective tools to keep cats away from wires, but they shouldn’t be your only strategy. Giving your kitty lots of quality time and enriching toys is another important way to keep them content (while keeping your wires intact).

steps.title: Take your cat to the vet if you’re worried they’ve hurt themselves.
steps.content: Take your cat to the vet if you’re worried they’ve hurt themselves. Electrical cords can create serious injuries like burns, along with even more serious conditions like seizures, respiratory issues, pulmonary edemas, and more. If your cat displays any type of concerning symptom after chewing on a wire, take them to a vet as soon as possible. [23] X Research source
